awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Cross-Layer Power-Bounded High Performance Computing on Emerging and Future Heterogeneous Computer Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Highly efficient and scalable computing systems are crucial to scientific discovery and technology innovation critical to national security and human society. However, the scalability of HPC systems is increasingly constrained by the power requirement and the necessity to limit the power density of components and server rooms. Comprising millions of components, today?s HPC systems already consume megawatts of power; to meet an insatiate demand for performance from mission-critical applications, future systems will consist of even more components and consume more power. To resolve the conflicting needs of scaling performance and limiting power, this research develops enabling technology for efficient and scalable computing on emerging and future computer systems bounded by power budgets.

The proposed power-bounded HPC approach recognizes power as a scarce resource and exploits hardware overprovisioning to scale performance within a power budget. Targeting at emerging heterogeneous HPC clusters comprising power-aware multicore CPUs and manycore accelerators, this research studies how to utilize all available power to maximize performance and power efficiency at component, node, and cluster levels for a wide range of applications. Specifically, this research (1) designs a novel application-aware cross-component scheduling system for power-bounded multicore computing, (2) creates a cooperative hybrid computing framework for power-bounded heterogeneous computing, and (3) develops analytical models and techniques to support large scale power-bounded computing. The completion of this research promotes novel system and software designs that efficiently utilize every watt of power on computation; the resulting analytical models form the theoretical foundation for designing future HPC systems, architectures, and building blocks. This project integrates educational components that engage graduate and undergraduate students in innovative HPC research, and broaden the participation of underrepresented and K-12 students.

por.por_cntn:
Modern computer systems are progressively limited by the available or allowed power at various layers, from individual components to data centers. To address this challenge, it is crucial to comprehend how power constraints affect performance, particularly for systems that have multiple power-hungry components and accelerators. Setting an inappropriate power limit on a node or component can significantly impair performance, and obtaining optimal performance-power efficiency necessitates coordinating power allocation among nodes and components.

The primary objectives of the project are to create innovative models and methods for power-bounded computing at the node and cluster levels. The research objectives consist of the following: (1) devising a new cross-component scheduling system for power-bounded multicore computing; (2) designing a cooperative hybrid computing framework for power-bounded heterogeneous computing; and (3) developing scalability models and techniques to support large-scale power-bounded computing. The goals have been attained through the following activities, and their outcomes are summarized below.

Research activities. Numerous research activities were supported through this grant, including analytical performance and scalability modeling; performance and power profiling and analysis, modeling, and optimization; power management strategies and software development; and power efficient algorithms for dense and sparse data. All these research activities focus on both homogeneous and heterogeneous manycore computing. These activities have produced several innovative performance models, algorithms, resource schedulers, and computing paradigms for power-constrained computing.

Publications. By the time of submitting this report, more than 16 peer-reviewed papers have been published in highly recognized IEEE/ACM sponsored journals, conferences/workshops, which include the IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems (TPDS), ACM Transactions on Parallel Computing (TOPC), the International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis (Supercomputing), the ACM International Conference on Supercomputing (ICS), the International Parallel and Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS).  the International Conference on Parallel Processing (ICPP). In addition, one paper is in preparation for resubmission. 

Ph.D. dissertations. This project consists of research questions that form the basis of three separate PhD dissertations. 

  1. Pengfei Zou. Power Bounded Computing on Current & Emerging HPC (2020). https://tigerprints.clemson.edu/all_dissertations/2618.
  2. Zheng Miao. Scalable and Reliable Sparse Data Computation on Emergent High Performance Computing Systems (2022). 
  3. Tyler Allen. Holistic Performance Analysis and Optimization of Unified Virtual Memory (2022). https://tigerprints.clemson.edu/all_dissertations/3092.

Training: 6 graduate students and more than 8 undergraduate students participated in the research activities. These research activities helped the students gain research experiences and interests in high performance computing. Several students made impressive achievements. Tyler Allen and Zheng Miao started as tenure-track faculty in research universities, and Thomas Randall (with co-authors Tyler Allen and PI Ge) won the Best Paper Award at International Conference on Supercomputing. 4 REU students continued for PhD studies (Thomas Randall, Bennett Cooper, and Nathan Jones joined PI Ge?s research lab at Clemson, and Derek Rodriguez joined Northeastern University). Each PhD student has done one or more summer internships with DOE national labs and co-authored with DOE researchers.  

Classroom education: The research findings derived from this grant have been integrated into various levels of classes taught by the PI. PI Ge created a graduate course (CPSC8810: Energy Efficient High Performance Computing) at Clemson University where over 30 Masters and Ph.D. students worked on related advanced course projects. She also integrates research findings as course modules to the graduate course CPSC8200: Parallel Architectures, which she regularly teaches, and the undergraduate course CPSC3300: Computer Organization which she frequently teaches. 

Broader impact. The PI strives to attract minority students to the research projects supported by this grant. Wayne Ellerbe is an exemplary minority student and a first-generation college student. He worked with PI Ge for multiple semesters on roofline model for deep learning models and frameworks on different GPU architectures. 

Released software and data. Multiple software and data ( e.g., software components in Pengfei Zou?s, Zheng Miao?s, and Tyler Allen?s dissertations) have been made available to the public and for reproduction.

In summary, PI Ge has achieved the proposed objectives in power-bounded computing on heterogeneous systems. The research project has created multiple opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to participate and gain valuable research experiences. The research approaches and results have been incorporated into both undergraduate and graduate-level courses to benefit a broad student community. All published papers have been made publicly accessible through the internet, contributing to national and international research and education communities in energy-efficient computing.
